review.title: The effect of linguistic constraints on the large scale organization of language
review.abstract: This paper studies the effect of linguistic constraints on the large scale organization of language. It describes the properties of linguistic networks built using texts of written language with the words randomized. These properties are compared to those obtained for a network built over the text in natural order. It is observed that the "random" networks too exhibit small-world and scale-free characteristics. They also show a high degree of clustering. This is indeed a surprising result - one that has not been addressed adequately in the literature. We hypothesize that many of the network statistics reported here studied are in fact functions of the distribution of the underlying data from which the network is built and may not be indicative of the nature of the concerned network.

metadata.title: The effect of linguistic constraints on the large scale organization of language

sections.text: This paper examines the effects of linguistic constraints on the large-scale organization of language. It describes the characteristics of linguistic networks that are built using texts of written language with randomly generated words, and compares these characteristics with those obtained for a network that has been built above the text in a natural order. It is observed that even the "random" networks exhibit petty-worldly and scale-free characteristics, as well as a high degree of clustering. Indeed, this is a surprising finding - one that has not been adequately considered in the literature. We assume that many of the network statistics studied here are actually functions of distributing the data underlying the network, and may not indicate the nature of the network in question.

sections.heading: 5 Conclusion
sections.text: We investigated the topological properties of linguistic networks at different levels of linguistic constraints. We found that the networks that emerge from randomly generated data have small worlds and scale-free characteristics. One possible explanation would be that degree distributions are functions of word frequencies. However, human language is a very complex "system," and there is no easy way to explain this observation. We also found that the degree distribution of a co-event diagram changes under randomization. Furthermore, network statistics such as diameter and cluster coefficient also seem to depend on the degree distributions of the underlying network.1920212223242526272829
